results.title: Fatal attraction
results.creator_credit: Adrian Lyne, Sherry Lansing, Stanley R. Jaffe and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: Michael Douglas, Glenn Close and Anne Archer star in this gripping, if at times inconsistent thriller. A passionate week-end encounter ends Dan Gallagher’s perfect life. Alex refuses to be a woman scorned and her capacity for revenge and violence is without limit. The conclusion is unforgettably shattering as the nightmare draws to its inevitable “bloody” climax. Glenn Close gives an excellent, terrifying performance as the homicidal Alex as the film grapples with men’s subconscious fears about women.

constellations_other.name: Femme fatales to fembots
constellations_other.description: When women gain power, men get scared. You can see this in the mysterious, seductive and deadly femme fatale. Using her sexuality and intellect to manipulate, control and co-opt power, the femme fatale reflects prevailing attitudes to women.

results.title: Reaction: portrait of a society in crisis
results.creator_credit: Robin Spry, Normand Cloutier, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: People from various English-speaking groups in Montreal and other places in Quebec express their personal reactions to the October Crisis of 1970 when Quebec nationalism took a violent turn. A British diplomat had been kidnapped, a Quebec cabinet minister murdered. The troops were brought in as a safeguard. This film is a vigorous reflection of the discussions and analyses of the situation that went on wherever people gathered, voicing attitudes and fears, sympathies and concerns.

results.title: Reaching out: Ken Tyler - master printer
results.creator_credit: Sid Avery, Lee Tirce, Tirce Productions and Avery
results.brief_description: Highlights the relationship between the printer and artist by focusing on Ken Tyler who has worked with many significant artists including Roy Lichtenstein, David Hockney, and Robert Rauschenberg. He has influenced these artists in refining and enlarging upon the boundaries of the printmaking art. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Reaching out: a story about mainstreaming
results.creator_credit: John Cosgrove, Terry Dunn, Walt Disney Productions and Educational Media
results.brief_description: Looks at the difficulties and rewards of integrating the handicapped into regular classrooms. Shows Mary, a severely deaf child with limited speech capabilities and cerebral palsy, and how she copes with mainstreaming.

results.title: Under the one roof
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ageing in the New Age”.
Some cultures such as the Australian Aboriginal, Western Samoan and Chinese still maintain traditions of respect and status for their older members. This film looks at some families in Australia (a country where the nuclear family is the norm) who are maintaining extended family life styles. Suitable for middle and upper secondary level.

results.title: The Other side of the coin
results.creator_credit: Stephen Ramsey, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ageing in the New Age”.
It’s hard in an affluent society to make do just on the pension. A couple show how they manage- what they do without and their wry but courageous philosophy of life.

results.title: Reaching out
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Connop, Suzanne Baker and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Ageing in the New Age”.
Looks at an experiment where the community is benefitting from utilising the previously wasted skill and wisdom of its old people. The results have two-way benefits: the older people feel happy to be contributing, and those helped are grateful for the assistance coming from the aged. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Real inside
results.creator_credit: John Weldon, David Verrall, Derek Lamb, Douglas MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Meet Buck Boom—dynamic, forceful and creative—and a candidate for the job of executive assistant at a staid corporation. There’s no doubt in Boom’s mind that he’s the person for the job, but the question is, can he convince Mr. Mudgin, the personnel manager? For, you see, Boom is a cartoon and Mudgin is not used to dealing with someone who is “different.” Skillfully crafted, using an innovative combination of live action and animation techniques, this hilarious short film probes stereotypes, prejudices and hiring practices.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Weldon, David Verrall, Derek Lamb, Douglas MacDonald and National Film Board of Canada
